headline: Apple says most devices will come from India, Vietnam to avoid U.S. tariffs - National | Globalnews.ca
context: Apple CEO Tim Cook said Thursday that the majority of iPhones sold in the U.S. in the current fiscal quarter will be sourced from India, while iPads and other devices will come from Vietnam as the company works to avoid the impact of President Donald Trump’s tariffs on its business.

Apple’s earnings for the first three months of the year topped Wall Street’s expectations thanks to high demand for its iPhones, and the company said tariffs had a limited effect on the fiscal second quarter’s results.

annotations.paragraph: Cook added that for the current quarter, assuming things don’t change, Apple expects to see $900 million added to its costs as a result of the tariffs, but Cook said the company remains “confident” in this business.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific financial impact details and Cook's commentary on the tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: The Cupertino, California-based company earned $24.78 billion, or $1.65 per share, in the first three months of the year, up 4.8% from $23.64 billion, or $1.53 per share, in the same period a year earlier.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific financial results relevant to Apple's performance amid tariff concerns.

annotations.paragraph: Story continues below advertisement
annotations.reason: This is a placeholder for an advertisement and does not contribute to the article's content.

annotations.paragraph: Revenue rose 5.1% to $95.36 billion from $90.75 billion.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific financial data relevant to Apple's performance.

annotations.paragraph: Analysts, on average, were expecting earnings of $1.62 per share on revenue of $94.19 billion, according to a poll by FactSet.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on analyst expectations, relevant to understanding Apple's performance.

																									Tech Talk: Amazon’s satellite launch & tariffs boost iPhone sales
annotations.reason: This is an image caption and does not contribute new information to the article.

annotations.paragraph: The numbers for the January-March period provide a snapshot of how Apple was faring before President Trump’s unveiling of sweeping tariffs in April that rattled the financial markets amid fears a trade war would reignite inflation and shove the U.S. economy into a recession.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on Apple's performance before the tariffs, relevant to understanding the impact of the tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Get expert insights, Q&A on markets, housing, inflation, and personal finance information delivered to you every Saturday.
annotations.reason: This is a promotional paragraph unrelated to the article's main topic.

annotations.paragraph: “While it is likely that some of the sales growth was driven by consumers accelerating purchases ahead of expected tariff increases, margins remained healthy on the other side of the balance sheet,” said Thomas Monteiro, an analyst at Investing.com.
annotations.reason: This quote provides analysis on the impact of tariffs on Apple's sales and margins, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: He added that the company “still has room for maneuver” regardless of the economic backdrop and will “likely not need to significantly deplete cash reserves to keep moving the needle.”
annotations.reason: This quote offers insight into Apple's financial strategy in response to tariffs, relevant to the article's topic.

annotations.paragraph: Story continues below advertisement
annotations.reason: This is a placeholder text for an advertisement, not contributing to the article's content.

annotations.paragraph: Apple’s reliance on Chinese factories to make its iPhones and other devices thrust the technology trendsetter into the crosshairs of Trump’s trade war. The exposure caused Apple’s stock price to plunge 23% shortly after the president announced the severity of the reciprocal tariffs, temporarily erasing $773 billion in shareholder wealth in the process.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on Apple's previous reliance on Chinese factories and the impact of tariffs on its stock price.

annotations.paragraph: Most of those losses have since been recovered after Trump temporarily exempted iPhones and other electronics from the reciprocal tariffs, but Apple’s stock remains down by nearly 5% since the April fusillade of tariffs.
annotations.reason: This paragraph updates on the recovery of Apple's stock and the ongoing impact of tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Besides the trade war, Apple has been hurt by its inability to live up to its own hype surrounding artificial intelligence features on the iPhone 16 lineup that came out last fall.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a separate issue unrelated to the main topic of tariffs and sourcing changes.

annotations.paragraph: Conservative MP will resign Alberta riding so Poilievre can run again
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to Apple's sourcing strategy or tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: The technology wasn’t ready when the iPhone 16 went on sale. Some AI features have rolled out in parts of the world as part of software updates, but Apple still hasn’t been able to live up to its original promise to make Siri smarter and more versatile. The missteps prompted Apple to pull advertising campaigns promoting AI breakthroughs on the iPhone, although the company still intends to release more features powered by the technology at some point.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses AI features and advertising, not Apple's sourcing strategy or tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Story continues below advertisement
annotations.reason: This is a placeholder text and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: Apple had been counting on its late entry into the AI craze to revive demand for the iPhone after last year’s sales dipped 2% from 2023’s levels. Apple said Wednesday that its phone sales climbed 1.9% to $46.84 billion for the first three months of the year. Wall Street had expected iPhone sales of $45.62 billion.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on Apple's sales performance, which is relevant to the company's overall strategy.

annotations.paragraph: But the company continues to see its China business decline, with revenue from the Greater China region down 2.3% to $16 billion for the quarter. Other regions, including the Americas, Europe and the rest of Asia, saw sales increases.
annotations.reason: Provides relevant context about Apple's regional sales performance, which is pertinent to the discussion of sourcing changes.

annotations.paragraph: When Trump initially indicated his 145% tariffs on Chinese-made goods would apply to the iPhone, U.S. consumers rushed to stores to buy new devices rather than risk prices spiking higher after the duties began driving up costs. But the flurry of panic buying won’t show up until Apple reports its results for the April-June quarter this summer.
annotations.reason: Offers relevant context on consumer behavior in response to tariffs, which is directly related to the article's focus on tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Trump’s trade war has ramped up the pressure on Cook to work the same diplomatic sleight of hand that enabled the iPhone to avoid being stung by the China tariffs that the president imposed during his first administration.
annotations.reason: Provides relevant context on the strategic challenges faced by Apple due to tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Cook signaled his intention remain on good terms with Trump by arranging private meetings with him and personally donating $1 million to the president’s second inauguration ceremony before sitting on the dais when Trump was sworn into office on January 20. Apple subsequently announced plans to invest $500 billion in the U.S. while hiring 20,000 workers during the next four years.
annotations.reason: Offers relevant context on Apple's strategic political maneuvers in response to tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Story continues below advertisement
annotations.reason: This is a placeholder for an advertisement and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: Trump’s trade war also is prompting a push to Apple to shift all the production of the iPhones that it sells in the U.S. from China to India, where the company has been building up its supply chain for the past seven years, according to a recent story in the Financial Times. But the complicated logistics of making such a huge move likely couldn’t be completed until next year, at the earliest, leaving Apple vulnerable to the vagaries of Trump’s trade war.
annotations.reason: Provides context on Apple's production shift and challenges due to tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Apple’s stock fell $5.81, or 2.7%, to $207.51 in after-hours trading.
annotations.reason: Reports on Apple's stock movement, relevant to financial impact.
